Hi @untwal. Changing the logline to:
```
self.log.info("Loaded %s into %s rows so far", i, table)
```
Would also solve the issue and make the code a bit more beautiful. Introducing this `i = 0` is a hack in my opinion.

Hi @Fokko, but this variable won't be present because these rows are empty, will throw a NameError at 225 line. I can better write it as 
```python
self.log.info("Done loading. Loaded a total of {0} rows".format(locals().get('i', 0)))
```
this `i` get define after the `for loop` starts, will not be defined if rows are empty

LOL, I was looking at the wrong line. I'm sorry. My suggestion would be:
```
self.log.info("Done loading. Loaded a total of %s rows", len(rows))
```
Having this mutable variable that is possibly being overwritten is not so nice.

@Fokko this `len()` will throw error for other types like if someone is writing it using some cursor like for `SomeDBToDBOperators`, just checked for my own custom written operator for `postgresqlToPostgresqlOperator`
@Fokko `i` here serves as the counter only for the rows so this makes sense to set it to zero at the start, if you suggest something else, I can change it again.

> When BigQueryPandasConnector encounters a BQ job insertion error, the exception will be assigned to connector.http_error, which is defined in parent connector GbqConnector but uninitialized.

This attribute was added in [`pandas-gbq == 0.3.0`](https://github.com/pydata/pandas-gbq/blob/0.3.0/pandas_gbq/gbq.py#L176).

> Curious, did Pandas make a backwards incompatible change to their API?

For what we're doing, `pandas-gbq` changed dramatically. We override the constructor to set `self.service` ourselves, but that attribute no longer exists:

https://github.com/pydata/pandas-gbq/blob/0.2.1/pandas_gbq/gbq.py#L213
https://github.com/pydata/pandas-gbq/blob/0.3.0/pandas_gbq/gbq.py#L185

When I pinned my local install to 0.2.1, I got the [following error](https://github.com/pydata/pandas-gbq/blob/0.2.1/pandas_gbq/gbq.py#L27-L38):
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/airflow/contrib/hooks/bigquery_hook.py", line 93, in get_pandas_df
    connector = BigQueryPandasConnector(project, service, dialect=dialect)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/airflow/contrib/hooks/bigquery_hook.py", line 142, in __init__
    gbq_check_google_client_version()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/pandas_gbq/gbq.py", line 38, in _check_google_client_version
    _GOOGLE_API_CLIENT_VERSION))
ImportError: pandas requires google-api-python-client >= 1.6.0 for Google BigQuery support, current version 1.5.5
```

There's a deeper compatibility issue here.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/d760d63e1a141a43a4a43daee9abd54cf11c894b/setup.py#L129-L136
@cinhil o sorry about that. Wasn’t clear, and I thought it important enough to have it quick

@milanvdm  Thanks for taking a look!

I'm not _100%_ convinced myself either since I haven't run the code with CeleryExecutor :P but I am hopeful that this could potentially solve the issue in the distributed setup as well. Reason being:

When `clear` is called via the UI, the webserver will set the state of the LocalTaskJob to `shutdown`, this information is stored in the jobs table in the airflow metadata db.

The LocalTaskJob (which is created via `airflow run --local` command and is running in one of the workers) will heartbeat periodically, each time it will read from the db and check its own state , and once it detects that it needs to be shut down, it will attempt to "kill" itself, which will call the on_kill method that eventually sends a SIGTERM signal to the raw process that's doing the work... 

So the main idea being, the detection of a shutdown is via the db, so it should be able to successfully terminate the running process.

Would be great to have someone running CeleryExecutor or have experience with Celery to test this out. I'll see what I can do on my end as well.

@topedmaria After you fix your commit so that alphanumeric ordering of company names is maintained and after you squash your commits into a single one, then you will need to do a "git push --force origin master" where origin is your fork. Then, the PR will automatically update to show the single commit and the updated readme. You don't need to close/reopen the PR. Just push the newly squashed commit to origin.

@topedmaria if you look at the your commits in the PR, you will notice that none of them are from Jan 19. Remember, when you squash, not to "git pul"l again, since your squashed commit will get dropped. You need to squash and git force push.

Good question. I am new to airflow, even more to your testing framework.
the "+" symbol is lost by flask request when the URL is not encoded.
We could add a TestLogView in test_views.py with a non day truncated datetime, but we are already behind the issue, so it will not bring more testing coverage.
After some research, the truth is that we should not have used the + symbol in the URL because '+' is expected to replace spaces (https://www.w3.org/TR/html401/interact/forms.html#h-17.13.4.1). 
If you have any idea where I could add a test, I will be happy to help.

Thank you for your response @criccomini . This would break the existing DAGs but this commit can be included in 2.0. I have added documentation in `updating.md`, `integration.rst` and `code.rst` regarding the update. There were only 2 operators in `Airflow 1.9` namely: `GoogleCloudStorageDownloadOperator` and `GoogleCloudStorageToBigQueryOperator` but there has an addition of 3 more operators, hence I feel this will keep it organized and allow to add further GCS operators. Let me know your thoughts.

Also this is replicating the current implementation of `DataProc{*}Operators`, hence keeping consistency.
